title: Efficient Numerical Reconstruction of Wave Equation Sources via Droplet-Induced Asymptotics
summary:
In this paper, we develop and numerically implement a novel approach for solving the inverse source problem of the acoustic wave equation in three dimensions. By injecting a small high-contrast droplet into the medium, we exploit the resulting wave field perturbation measured at a single external point over time. The method enables stable source reconstructions where conventional approaches fail due to ill-posedness, with potential applications in medical imaging and non-destructive testing. Key contributions include:
  1. Implementation of a theoretically justified asymptotic expansion, from [33], using the eigensystem of the Newtonian operator, with error analysis for the spectral truncation.
  2. Novel numerical schemes for solving the time-domain Lippmann-Schwinger equation and reconstructing the source via Riesz basis expansions and mollification-based numerical differentiations.
  3. Reconstruction requiring only single-point measurements, overcoming traditional spatial data limitations.
  4. 3D numerical experiments demonstrating accurate source recovery under noise (SNR of the order $1/a$), with error analysis for the droplet size (of the order $a$) and the number of spectral modes $N$.

AI.tldr: A novel method for solving 3D acoustic wave inverse source problems using high-contrast droplet injection and single-point measurements, enabling stable reconstructions where conventional approaches fail.
AI.motivation: Conventional approaches to inverse source problems for acoustic wave equations suffer from ill-posedness and require extensive spatial measurements. There's a need for stable reconstruction methods that work with limited measurement data, particularly for applications in medical imaging and non-destructive testing.
AI.method: Inject a small high-contrast droplet into the medium and measure wave field perturbations at a single external point over time. Use asymptotic expansion based on the Newtonian operator eigensystem, solve time-domain Lippmann-Schwinger equation, employ Riesz basis expansions and mollification-based numerical differentiations for source reconstruction.
AI.result: The method enables stable source reconstructions with only single-point measurements. 3D numerical experiments demonstrate accurate source recovery under noise (SNR ~ 1/a), with error analysis for droplet size (order a) and number of spectral modes N.
AI.conclusion: The novel approach successfully overcomes ill-posedness in acoustic inverse source problems, requiring only single-point measurements while maintaining stability and accuracy, with promising applications in medical imaging and non-destructive testing.

title: A fully diagonalized spectral method on the unit ball
comment: This preprint has not undergone peer review or any post-submission improvements or corrections. The Version of Record of this article is published in Numerical Algorithms, and is available online at https://doi.org/10.1007/s11075-026-02315-w
summary: Our main objective in this work is to show how Sobolev orthogonal polynomials emerge as a useful tool within the framework of spectral methods for boundary-value problems. The solution of a boundary-value problem for a stationary Schrödinger equation on the unit ball can be studied from a variational perspective. In this variational formulation, a Sobolev inner product naturally arises. As test functions, we consider the linear space of the polynomials satisfying the boundary conditions on the sphere, and a basis of mutually orthogonal polynomials with respect to the Sobolev inner product is provided. The basis of the proposed method is given in terms of spherical harmonics and univariate Sobolev orthogonal polynomials. The connection formula between these Sobolev orthogonal polynomials and the classical orthogonal polynomials on the ball is established. Consequently, the Sobolev Fourier coefficients of a function satisfying the boundary value problem are recursively derived. Finally, one numerical experiment is presented.

AI.tldr: Sobolev orthogonal polynomials are introduced as a tool for spectral methods in solving boundary-value problems on the unit ball, particularly for stationary Schrödinger equations.
AI.motivation: To develop an efficient spectral method framework for boundary-value problems using Sobolev orthogonal polynomials that naturally arise from variational formulations of stationary Schrödinger equations on the unit ball.
AI.method: Uses variational formulation of boundary-value problems, constructs polynomial test functions satisfying boundary conditions, provides orthogonal basis with respect to Sobolev inner product using spherical harmonics and univariate Sobolev orthogonal polynomials, establishes connection to classical orthogonal polynomials, and recursively derives Sobolev Fourier coefficients.
AI.result: Developed a spectral method framework using Sobolev orthogonal polynomials, established connection formulas to classical polynomials, derived recursive computation of Sobolev Fourier coefficients, and presented numerical validation.
AI.conclusion: Sobolev orthogonal polynomials provide an effective spectral method tool for boundary-value problems on the unit ball, with practical computational advantages demonstrated through numerical experiments.

title: Canonical structure of the LLG equation for exponential updates in micromagnetism
summary: In this contribution we propose an exponential update algorithm for magnetic moments appearing in the framework of micromagnetics and the Landau-Lifshitz-Gilbert (LLG) equation. This algorithm can be interpreted as the geometric integration on spheres, that a priori satisfy the unit length constraint of the normalized magnetization vector. Even though the geometric structures for this are obvious and some works already use an exponential algorithm, to the best of the authors' knowledge, there is no canonical structure of the LLG equation for the exponential update algorithm in micromagnetism. Tensor algebraic reformulations of the LLG equation allow the canonical representation of the evolution equation for the magnetization, which serves as the basis for different integrators. Based on the specific structure of the exponential of skew symmetric matrices an efficient update scheme is derived. The excellent performance of the proposed exponential update algorithm is demonstrated in representative examples.

AI.tldr: Proposes an exponential update algorithm for magnetic moments in micromagnetics that preserves the unit length constraint of magnetization vectors through geometric integration on spheres.
AI.motivation: To develop a canonical exponential update algorithm for the Landau-Lifshitz-Gilbert equation that properly handles the geometric constraint of unit-length magnetization vectors, addressing the lack of canonical structure for such algorithms in micromagnetism.
AI.method: Uses tensor algebraic reformulations of the LLG equation to create canonical representation of magnetization evolution, then derives an efficient update scheme based on the structure of exponential of skew symmetric matrices, enabling geometric integration on spheres.
AI.result: The proposed exponential update algorithm demonstrates excellent performance in representative examples, showing effectiveness in preserving the unit length constraint while solving micromagnetics problems.
AI.conclusion: The exponential update algorithm provides a geometrically consistent and efficient method for simulating magnetic moments in micromagnetics, offering a canonical structure for exponential integration of the LLG equation while maintaining the fundamental constraint of unit magnetization vectors.

title: A hybrid reconstruction of piece-wise smooth functions from non-uniform Fourier data
summary: In this paper, we consider the problem of reconstructing piece-wise smooth functions from their non-uniform Fourier data. We first extend the filter method for uniform Fourier data to the non-uniform setting by using the techniques of admissible frames. We show that the proposed non-uniform filter method converges exponentially away from the jump discontinuities. However, the convergence rate is significantly slower near the jump discontinuities due to the Gibbs phenomenon. To overcome this issue, we combine the non-uniform filter method with a stable extrapolation method to recover the function values near the jump discontinuities. We show that the proposed hybrid method could achieve exponential accuracy uniformly on the entire domain. Numerical experiments are provided to demonstrate the performance of the proposed method.

AI.tldr: A hybrid method combining non-uniform filter reconstruction with stable extrapolation achieves exponential accuracy for piece-wise smooth functions from non-uniform Fourier data, overcoming Gibbs phenomenon near discontinuities.
AI.motivation: Reconstructing piece-wise smooth functions from non-uniform Fourier data is challenging due to Gibbs phenomenon near jump discontinuities, which causes slow convergence in standard filter methods.
AI.method: Extends filter method to non-uniform Fourier data using admissible frames, then combines it with stable extrapolation to recover function values near jump discontinuities, creating a hybrid approach.
AI.result: The non-uniform filter method alone converges exponentially away from discontinuities but slowly near jumps; the hybrid method achieves exponential accuracy uniformly across the entire domain.
AI.conclusion: The proposed hybrid method effectively overcomes Gibbs phenomenon limitations, providing uniformly exponential accurate reconstruction of piece-wise smooth functions from non-uniform Fourier data.

title: Asymptotic scaling theory of electrostatic turbulent transport in magnetised fusion plasmas
summary: Turbulent transport remains one of the principal obstacles to achieving efficient magnetic confinement in fusion devices. Two of the dominant drivers of the turbulence are microscale instabilities fuelled by electron- and ion-temperature gradients (ETG and ITG), whose nonlinear saturation determines the cross-field transport of particles and energy. Despite decades of study, predictive modelling of this turbulence has been limited either to expensive gyrokinetic simulations or to reduced models calibrated by fitting to numerical or experimental data, restricting their utility for reactor design. Here we present a simple asymptotic scaling theory that unifies ETG- and ITG-driven turbulence within a common framework. By balancing the fundamental time scales of linear growth, nonlinear decorrelation, and parallel propagation, the theory isolates the dependence of the heat flux on equilibrium parameters to two key quantities: the parallel system scale and the outer-scale aspect ratio. We show that these quantities encapsulate the essential physics of saturation, leading to distinct predictions for ETG and ITG transport: a cubic scaling with the temperature gradient in the electron channel, and a linear scaling in the ion channel. Extensive nonlinear gyrokinetic simulations confirm that these theoretical predictions hold irrespective of the magnetic geometry (slab, tokamak, or stellarator), including the first numerical confirmation of the cubic ETG scaling anticipated by earlier theory. By isolating the dependence on just the parallel system scale and the outer-scale aspect ratio, our framework provides a physics-based foundation for fast, geometry-aware transport models, offering a pathway toward reactor optimisation in both tokamaks and stellarators.

AI.tldr: A new scaling theory unifies electron- and ion-temperature-gradient-driven turbulence in fusion devices, predicting cubic scaling for ETG transport and linear scaling for ITG transport, validated by gyrokinetic simulations across magnetic geometries.
AI.motivation: Turbulent transport is a major obstacle to efficient magnetic confinement in fusion devices. Current predictive modeling is limited to expensive gyrokinetic simulations or reduced models calibrated to data, restricting utility for reactor design.
AI.method: Developed a simple asymptotic scaling theory that unifies ETG- and ITG-driven turbulence by balancing fundamental time scales (linear growth, nonlinear decorrelation, parallel propagation). The theory isolates heat flux dependence to two key quantities: parallel system scale and outer-scale aspect ratio.
AI.result: Theory predicts distinct scalings: cubic scaling with temperature gradient for ETG transport and linear scaling for ITG transport. Extensive nonlinear gyrokinetic simulations confirm these predictions across magnetic geometries (slab, tokamak, stellarator), including first numerical confirmation of cubic ETG scaling.
AI.conclusion: The framework provides a physics-based foundation for fast, geometry-aware transport models, offering a pathway toward reactor optimization in both tokamaks and stellarators by isolating dependence on just two key parameters.

title: Bayesian identification of fibrous insulation thermal conductivity towards design of spacecraft thermal protection systems
summary: The design of spacecraft thermal protection systems (TPS) requires accurate knowledge of thermal transport properties across wide ranges of temperature and pressure. For fibrous insulation, conventional measurement techniques in laboratory settings are typically limited to temperatures much lower than what is reached in atmosphere entry scenarios. Moreover, it is often the case that only temperature measurements are available, meaning that the thermal conductivity of the insulation must be indirectly inferred as an inverse problem. We propose a Bayesian framework using information field theory (IFT) to reconstruct the thermal conductivity of high-temperature fibrous insulation from sparse experimental data. Under IFT, the conductivity is represented as a Gaussian process, and the physics is enforced via a physics-informed prior over the temperature derived from the heat equation. Bayes's rule produces an infinite-dimensional posterior distribution that quantifies uncertainty about the conductivity which can be evaluated in extrapolation regimes. We apply the method to Opacified Fibrous Insulation with both synthetic and experimental data to reconstruct the thermal conductivity beyond the experimental regime. The inferred conductivities are validated against reference data and then propagated into high-fidelity digital twins of flexible TPS performance under Mars and Earth entry trajectories. The results show that IFT yields accurate predictions with quantified uncertainty, enabling robust TPS sizing in regimes inaccessible to direct measurement.

AI.tldr: Bayesian framework using information field theory reconstructs thermal conductivity of high-temperature fibrous insulation from sparse data, enabling accurate TPS design for extreme entry conditions.
AI.motivation: Spacecraft thermal protection systems require accurate thermal conductivity data at extreme temperatures encountered during atmospheric entry, but conventional lab measurements are limited to lower temperatures, and often only temperature measurements are available, requiring indirect inference.
AI.method: Bayesian framework using information field theory (IFT) where conductivity is represented as a Gaussian process, with physics enforced via a physics-informed prior over temperature derived from the heat equation. The method produces an infinite-dimensional posterior distribution quantifying uncertainty.
AI.result: The method successfully reconstructs thermal conductivity beyond experimental regimes for Opacified Fibrous Insulation using both synthetic and experimental data. Validated against reference data and propagated into high-fidelity digital twins for Mars and Earth entry trajectories.
AI.conclusion: IFT yields accurate predictions with quantified uncertainty, enabling robust thermal protection system sizing in regimes inaccessible to direct measurement, addressing critical needs for spacecraft design.

title: A tensor network formalism for neuro-symbolic AI
summary: The unification of neural and symbolic approaches to artificial intelligence remains a central open challenge. In this work, we introduce a tensor network formalism, which captures sparsity principles originating in the different approaches in tensor decompositions. In particular, we describe a basis encoding scheme for functions and model neural decompositions as tensor decompositions. The proposed formalism can be applied to represent logical formulas and probability distributions as structured tensor decompositions. This unified treatment identifies tensor network contractions as a fundamental inference class and formulates efficiently scaling reasoning algorithms, originating from probability theory and propositional logic, as contraction message passing schemes. The framework enables the definition and training of hybrid logical and probabilistic models, which we call Hybrid Logic Network. The theoretical concepts are accompanied by the python library tnreason, which enables the implementation and practical use of the proposed architectures.

AI.tldr: Tensor network formalism unifies neural and symbolic AI by representing logical formulas and probability distributions as structured tensor decompositions, enabling hybrid logical-probabilistic models.
AI.motivation: The unification of neural and symbolic approaches to artificial intelligence remains a central open challenge. Current approaches lack a common formalism that can capture sparsity principles from both paradigms.
AI.method: Introduces a tensor network formalism with basis encoding for functions, models neural decompositions as tensor decompositions, and represents logical formulas and probability distributions as structured tensor decompositions. Identifies tensor network contractions as fundamental inference class and formulates reasoning algorithms as contraction message passing schemes.
AI.result: Develops a framework for defining and training hybrid logical and probabilistic models called Hybrid Logic Network. Provides theoretical concepts accompanied by the python library tnreason for practical implementation and use of the proposed architectures.
AI.conclusion: Tensor networks provide a unified formalism for neural and symbolic AI, enabling hybrid models that combine logical reasoning with probabilistic inference through efficient tensor contraction algorithms.

title: Discovery of Density Limit Disruption Induced by Core-localized Alfv${é}$nic Ion Temperature Gradient Instabilities in a Tokamak Plasma
summary: To achieve a high energy gain, the fusion reactor plasma must reach a very high density. However, the tokamak plasmas ofen undergo disruption when the density exceeds the Greenwald density. The density limit disruption in tokamak plasmas is a mysterious barrier to magnetic confinement nuclear fusion, and hitherto, is still an unresolved issue. Over the past several years, the high density experiments with Greenwald density ratio $n_e/n_{eG}\sim1$ has been carried out using the conventional gas-puff fuelling method in HL-2A NBI and Ohmically heated plasmas. It is found for the first time that there are multiple-branch MHD instabilities in the core plasmas while $n_e/n_{eG}>0.85$. The simulation analysis suggests that the core-localized magnetohydrodynamics (MHD) activities belong to Alfv${é}$nic ion temperature gradient (AITG) modes, and on experiment firstly, it is discovered that they trigger the minor or major disruption of bulk plasmas while the density is peaked. These new findings are of great importance to figure out and understand the origin of density limit disruptions, as well as to forecast and avoid them for future fusion rectors.

AI.tldr: First discovery of multiple-branch MHD instabilities in tokamak core plasmas at high densities (ne/neG > 0.85), identified as Alfvénic ion temperature gradient (AITG) modes, which trigger minor or major disruptions when density is peaked.
AI.motivation: The density limit disruption in tokamak plasmas remains an unresolved barrier to magnetic confinement nuclear fusion, preventing reactors from achieving the high densities needed for optimal energy gain. Understanding and overcoming this limitation is crucial for future fusion reactors.
AI.method: Conducted high-density experiments on HL-2A tokamak using conventional gas-puff fueling method in NBI and Ohmically heated plasmas. Used simulation analysis to identify the nature of observed MHD instabilities.
AI.result: First experimental discovery of multiple-branch MHD instabilities in core plasmas when density exceeds 85% of Greenwald density. Simulations identify these as Alfvénic ion temperature gradient (AITG) modes that trigger minor or major disruptions when density becomes peaked.
AI.conclusion: These findings provide crucial insights into the origin of density limit disruptions, offering new understanding that could enable forecasting and avoidance of such disruptions in future fusion reactors, potentially overcoming a major barrier to achieving high-density operation.

title: Equivariant Interatomic Potentials without Tensor Products
summary: Foundational machine-learned interatomic potentials have emerged as powerful tools for atomistic simulations, promising near first-principles accuracy across diverse chemical spaces at a fraction of the cost of quantum-mechanical calculations. However, the most accurate equivariant architectures rely on Clebsch-Gordan tensor products whose computational cost scales steeply with angular resolution, creating a trade-off between model expressiveness and inference speed that ultimately limits practical applications. Here we introduce Geodite, an equivariant message-passing architecture that replaces tensor products while incorporating physical priors to ensure smooth, well-behaved potential energy surfaces. Trained on the Materials Project trajectories dataset of inorganic crystals, Geodite-MP achieves accuracy competitive with leading methods on benchmarks for materials stability prediction, thermal conductivity, phonon-derived properties, and nanosecond-scale molecular dynamics, while running $3\text{--}5\times$ faster than models performing similarly. By combining predictive accuracy, computational efficiency, and physicality, Geodite enables faster large-scale atomistic simulations and high-throughput screening that would otherwise be computationally prohibitive.

AI.tldr: Geodite is a new equivariant message-passing architecture that replaces computationally expensive Clebsch-Gordan tensor products, achieving competitive accuracy with 3-5x faster inference speed for atomistic simulations.
AI.motivation: Current accurate equivariant architectures rely on Clebsch-Gordan tensor products that create a trade-off between model expressiveness and inference speed, limiting practical applications of machine-learned interatomic potentials.
AI.method: Geodite replaces tensor products with an equivariant message-passing architecture that incorporates physical priors to ensure smooth, well-behaved potential energy surfaces.
AI.result: Geodite-MP achieves accuracy competitive with leading methods on benchmarks for materials stability prediction, thermal conductivity, phonon-derived properties, and nanosecond-scale molecular dynamics, while running 3-5x faster than similarly performing models.
AI.conclusion: Geodite enables faster large-scale atomistic simulations and high-throughput screening that would otherwise be computationally prohibitive by combining predictive accuracy, computational efficiency, and physicality.

title: Density Limit Experiments and Core-localized Kinetic MHD Activities in HL-2A Ohmic Heating Plasmas
summary: The density limit is a mysterious barrier to magnetic confinement nuclear fusion, and is still an unresolved issue. In this paper, we will present the experimental results of the density limit and core-localized kinetic MHD instabilities on HL-2A. Firstly, the high density shots with $ne/ne_G>1$ have been achieved by the conventional gas-puff fuelling method in Ohmic heating plasmas, and the corresponding duration time is close to $t\sim500$ ms ($\sim$ $30τ_E$), where $τ_E$ is the global energy confinement time. Secondly, it is found for the first time that there are kinetic MHD instabilities in the core plasmas while $ne/ne_G\sim1$. The analysis suggests that the core-localized MHD activities belong to Alfv{é}nic ion temperature gradient (AITG) modes or kinetic ballooning modes (KBM), and firstly it is found on experiment that they trigger the minor or major disruption of bulk plasmas while the density profile is peaked. These new findings are of great importance to figure out and understand the origin of the density limit.

AI.tldr: Experimental study on HL-2A tokamak achieves high-density plasmas (ne/ne_G>1) and discovers core-localized kinetic MHD instabilities that trigger disruptions near density limit.
AI.motivation: To investigate the unresolved density limit problem in magnetic confinement fusion and understand its origin through experimental studies.
AI.method: Conducted experiments on HL-2A tokamak using conventional gas-puff fueling in Ohmic heating plasmas, achieving high-density shots with ne/ne_G>1 and analyzing core-localized MHD instabilities.
AI.result: 1) Achieved high-density plasmas (ne/ne_G>1) with duration ~500 ms (~30τ_E). 2) First-time discovery of core-localized kinetic MHD instabilities when ne/ne_G~1. 3) Identified these as Alfvénic ion temperature gradient (AITG) modes or kinetic ballooning modes (KBM) that trigger minor/major disruptions in peaked density profiles.
AI.conclusion: These new experimental findings of core-localized kinetic MHD instabilities near the density limit are crucial for understanding the origin of the density limit barrier in magnetic confinement fusion.

title: Convolutional LSTM Surrogate for Mesoscale Hydrocode Simulations of Granular Wave Propagation
summary: Granular materials subjected to impact loading exhibit highly heterogeneous spatiotemporal dynamics governed by wave propagation, pore collapse, and grain-scale rearrangements. Mesoscale hydrocodes resolve these processes but are computationally expensive, limiting their use in parametric studies and uncertainty quantification. In this work, we develop a convolutional Long Short-Term Memory (ConvLSTM) neural network as a spatiotemporal surrogate for mesoscale simulations of weak shock propagation in granular media. Using two-dimensional hydrocode simulations as training data, we first consider a simplified "billiard break" problem in which a cue ball impacts a cluster of nine circular balls, all deformable. Sequences of pressure-field images serve as input-output pairs for a sequence-to-sequence ConvLSTM, which is trained to predict future frames from a short history. We compare several architectures and show that a relatively compact encoder-decoder ConvLSTM accurately reproduces the propagation of the pressure wave and the resulting particle motion for an unseen combination of cue-ball position and impact velocity. As a proof-of-concept extension, we apply the same ConvLSTM framework to previously published mesoscale simulations of weak shock compaction in a granular ensemble. When evaluated at piston impact speeds that were completely withheld from training, the surrogate captures the position and shape of the compaction front and its dependence on impact speed, while smoothing fine pore-scale details in the highly compacted region as expected. These results demonstrate that ConvLSTM models can serve as satisfactory surrogates for spatiotemporal mesoscale simulations of granular wave propagation, enabling accelerated exploration of parameter space and laying the groundwork for physics-informed, mesoscale simulations of granular materials under shock loading.

AI.tldr: ConvLSTM neural network serves as spatiotemporal surrogate for expensive mesoscale simulations of shock propagation in granular materials, enabling faster parameter exploration.
AI.motivation: Mesoscale hydrocodes for granular materials under impact are computationally expensive, limiting parametric studies and uncertainty quantification. Need faster surrogate models.
AI.method: Develop convolutional LSTM (ConvLSTM) neural network as spatiotemporal surrogate. Train on 2D hydrocode simulation data of pressure-field images. Use sequence-to-sequence architecture to predict future frames from short history. Test on simplified "billiard break" problem and real granular shock compaction.
AI.result: Compact encoder-decoder ConvLSTM accurately reproduces pressure wave propagation and particle motion for unseen impact conditions. Captures compaction front position/shape and dependence on impact speed, while smoothing fine pore-scale details as expected.
AI.conclusion: ConvLSTM models can serve as satisfactory surrogates for spatiotemporal mesoscale simulations of granular wave propagation, enabling accelerated parameter space exploration and laying groundwork for physics-informed simulations.

title: Existence and uniqueness of $L^1$-solutions to time-fractional nonlinear diffusion equations
summary: We establish the global existence and uniqueness of $L^1$-solutions to the Cauchy problem for time-fractional porous medium type nonlinear diffusion equations. Furthermore, we give the mass conservation law for $L^1$-solutions to time-fractional fast diffusion equations, and prove that the finite-time extinction does not occur for any nonnegative $L^1$-solutions.

AI.tldr: Global existence and uniqueness of L¹-solutions for time-fractional porous medium equations, plus mass conservation and no finite-time extinction for time-fractional fast diffusion equations.
AI.motivation: To extend classical porous medium equation theory to time-fractional settings, establishing fundamental properties like existence, uniqueness, and conservation laws for these fractional nonlinear diffusion equations.
AI.method: Mathematical analysis of time-fractional porous medium type equations, focusing on L¹-solution spaces. Uses analytical techniques for fractional differential equations and nonlinear diffusion theory.
AI.result: Proved global existence and uniqueness of L¹-solutions for time-fractional porous medium equations. Established mass conservation law for time-fractional fast diffusion equations and showed finite-time extinction does not occur for nonnegative L¹-solutions.
AI.conclusion: Time-fractional porous medium equations behave fundamentally differently from classical ones - they maintain mass conservation and avoid finite-time extinction phenomena, providing new insights into fractional nonlinear diffusion processes.

title: A kinetic-moment framework for electron energy dynamics in capacitively coupled plasmas: absorption, conversion, transport, and dissipation
summary: Understanding electron energy dynamics in low-temperature plasmas such as capacitively coupled plasmas (CCPs), including energy absorption, conversion, transport, and dissipation, is essential for interpreting discharge physics and process applications. We propose a kinetic-moment framework based on particle-in-cell/Monte Carlo collision (PIC/MCC) simulations. The framework reconstructs the first three velocity moments of the Boltzmann equation directly from PIC/MCC data and enables a quantitative, self-consistent description of electron energy dynamics in low-pressure CCPs. To clarify energy conversion among electromagnetic energy, electron fluid kinetic (mechanical) energy, and electron thermal (internal) energy, we further separate the total energy transport equation into kinetic- and thermal-energy equations. We find that, at low pressure, electrons gain directed kinetic energy in the sheath and convert it locally into thermal energy through pressure-strain interaction and collisions. Thermal energy is then transported into the bulk and is dissipated mainly by inelastic electron-neutral collisions. We further decompose pressure-strain interaction into reversible pressure dilatation and irreversible viscous-like dissipation, which correspond to conversion driven by volumetric compression or expansion and by shear deformation, respectively. This decomposition reveals a significant thermalization channel beyond collisions. More broadly, the results show coexistence of localized kinetic-to-thermal conversion near the sheath and nonlocal energy transport from the sheath to the bulk dominated by microscopic heat flux. The heat flux deviates strongly from Fourier's law based on local temperature gradients. This framework provides a clear fluid description with kinetic fidelity and offers a practical tool for analyzing energy evolution in nonequilibrium plasmas.

AI.tldr: A kinetic-moment framework based on PIC/MCC simulations is developed to analyze electron energy dynamics in low-pressure capacitively coupled plasmas, revealing localized energy conversion near sheaths and nonlocal thermal transport dominated by microscopic heat flux.
AI.motivation: Understanding electron energy dynamics (absorption, conversion, transport, dissipation) in low-temperature plasmas like CCPs is essential for interpreting discharge physics and process applications, but requires a quantitative, self-consistent framework.
AI.method: Proposed a kinetic-moment framework based on PIC/MCC simulations that reconstructs the first three velocity moments of the Boltzmann equation directly from simulation data, enabling quantitative analysis of electron energy dynamics in low-pressure CCPs.
AI.result: At low pressure, electrons gain directed kinetic energy in the sheath and convert it locally into thermal energy through pressure-strain interaction and collisions. Thermal energy is transported into the bulk and dissipated mainly by inelastic electron-neutral collisions. Pressure-strain interaction decomposes into reversible pressure dilatation and irreversible viscous-like dissipation, revealing significant thermalization beyond collisions. Heat flux deviates strongly from Fourier's law based on local temperature gradients.
AI.conclusion: The framework provides a clear fluid description with kinetic fidelity, offering a practical tool for analyzing energy evolution in nonequilibrium plasmas. It reveals coexistence of localized kinetic-to-thermal conversion near sheaths and nonlocal energy transport dominated by microscopic heat flux.

title: Cost scaling of MPS and TTNS simulations for 2D and 3D systems with area-law entanglement
summary: Tensor network states are an indispensable tool for the simulation of strongly correlated quantum many-body systems. In recent years, tree tensor network states (TTNS) have been successfully used for two-dimensional systems and to benchmark quantum simulation approaches for condensed matter, nuclear, and particle physics. In comparison to the more traditional approach based on matrix product states (MPS), the graph distance of physical degrees of freedom can be drastically reduced in TTNS. Surprisingly, it turns out that, for large systems in $D>1$ spatial dimensions, MPS simulations of low-energy states are nevertheless more efficient than TTNS simulations. With a focus on $D=2$ and 3, the scaling of computational costs for different boundary conditions is determined under the assumption that the system obeys an entanglement (log-)area law, implying that bond dimensions scale exponentially in the surface area of the associated subsystems.

AI.tldr: TTNS reduce graph distances compared to MPS but surprisingly MPS remains more efficient for large D>1 systems despite TTNS's theoretical advantages.
AI.motivation: To understand why matrix product states (MPS) outperform tree tensor network states (TTNS) for large systems in D>1 spatial dimensions, despite TTNS having theoretical advantages in reducing graph distances between physical degrees of freedom.
AI.method: Analyzing computational cost scaling for D=2 and 3 systems under different boundary conditions, assuming entanglement area laws where bond dimensions scale exponentially with subsystem surface area.
AI.result: For large systems in D>1 dimensions, MPS simulations of low-energy states are more efficient than TTNS simulations, despite TTNS's ability to drastically reduce graph distances between physical degrees of freedom.
AI.conclusion: The theoretical advantage of TTNS in reducing graph distances doesn't translate to practical computational efficiency for large D>1 systems, with MPS remaining the more efficient approach for simulating low-energy states under entanglement area law assumptions.

title: Linear stability of the first bifurcation in a tumor growth free boundary problem via local bifurcation structure
summary: In this paper, we consider a 3-dimensional free boundary problem modeling tumor growth with the Robin boundary condition. The system involves a positive parameter $μ$ which reflects the intensity of tumor aggressiveness. Huang, Zhang and Hu [Nonlinear Anal. Real World Appl. 2017(35), 483-502] have shown that for each $μ_n$ ($n$ even) in a strictly increasing sequence $\{ μ_n \}(n\geq 2)$, there exists a stationary bifurcation solution $(σ_n(\varepsilon),p_n(\varepsilon),r_n(\varepsilon))$ with $μ= μ_n(\varepsilon)$ bifurcating from $μ_n$. We first derive that the bifurcation curve $(r_2(\varepsilon),μ_2(\varepsilon))$ exhibits a transcritical bifurcation with $μ_2'(0)<0$. Moreover, we show that the stationary bifurcation solution $(σ_2(\varepsilon),p_2(\varepsilon),r_2(\varepsilon))$ is linearly unstable for small $|\varepsilon|$ under non-radially symmetric perturbations. In contrast to the linear stability of the radially symmetric stationary solution, the lack of explicit expressions for bifurcation solutions adds great difficulty in analyzing their linear stability. The novelty of this paper lies in the use of the bifurcation curve's structure to overcome the above difficulties. Moreover, this linear stability result is not established using the standard method, due to an eight-dimensional generalized kernel at eigenvalue 0 for the linearized operator.

AI.tldr: The paper analyzes linear stability of bifurcation solutions in a 3D tumor growth model with Robin boundary conditions, showing transcritical bifurcation and instability under non-radially symmetric perturbations.
AI.motivation: Previous work showed existence of stationary bifurcation solutions in tumor growth models, but their stability analysis was challenging due to lack of explicit expressions and high-dimensional kernels in the linearized operator.
AI.method: Uses bifurcation curve structure to overcome difficulties in stability analysis, rather than standard methods. Specifically analyzes the transcritical bifurcation structure and handles the eight-dimensional generalized kernel at eigenvalue 0.
AI.result: Shows that the bifurcation curve exhibits transcritical bifurcation with μ₂'(0)<0, and proves the stationary bifurcation solution is linearly unstable for small perturbations under non-radially symmetric conditions.
AI.conclusion: The bifurcation solutions are linearly unstable despite radial symmetry stability, demonstrating the importance of considering non-radially symmetric perturbations in tumor growth models.

title: Non-Ambipolarity of Microturbulent Transport
summary: Even what is called electrostatic microturbulence produces a plasma-beta-dependent turbulent magnetic field $\tilde{B}$, which makes the magnetic field lines chaotic. Quasi-neutrality along the chaotic magnetic field lines requires a potential that obeys $\vec{B}\cdot \vec{\nabla} Φ= \vec{B}\cdot \vec{\nabla} p_e$, where $p_e$ is the electron pressure. This potential produces radial transport similar to that of diffusion coefficient $D_{ef}= (Δ/a_T)T_e/eB$. $Δ$ is the radial distance over which the potential $Φ$ is correlated by the electron motion along the chaotic magnetic field, and $|dT_e/dr| = T_e/a_T$. The chaos-produced electron transport gives an effective viscosity on the electron flow, which can counter balance a non-ambipolar part of the ion radial particle diffusion $f_{na}$. This non-ambipolarity would otherwise require a radial electric field that confines ions and hence impurities. The maximum $f_{na}$ that can be counterbalanced and the required plasma beta to avoid shielding the magnetic perturbations $\tilde{B}$ are calculated.

AI.tldr: Electrostatic microturbulence creates chaotic magnetic field lines, requiring a potential that causes radial electron transport, which provides effective viscosity to counterbalance non-ambipolar ion diffusion that would otherwise require impurity-confining radial electric fields.
AI.motivation: To understand how electrostatic microturbulence-induced chaotic magnetic field lines affect plasma transport and how electron transport can balance non-ambipolar ion diffusion to avoid requiring impurity-confining radial electric fields.
AI.method: Analysis of quasi-neutrality along chaotic magnetic field lines, derivation of potential equation, calculation of radial transport diffusion coefficient, and determination of effective electron viscosity to counterbalance non-ambipolar ion diffusion.
AI.result: Derived diffusion coefficient D_ef = (Δ/a_T)T_e/eB for radial transport, found electron transport provides effective viscosity to balance non-ambipolar ion diffusion f_na, and calculated maximum f_na that can be counterbalanced and required plasma beta to avoid shielding magnetic perturbations.
AI.conclusion: Electrostatic microturbulence-induced magnetic field chaos creates electron transport that can balance non-ambipolar ion diffusion, potentially avoiding the need for impurity-confining radial electric fields, with specific plasma beta requirements for this mechanism to work effectively.

title: Controlling HER activity and stability of $γ$- and 6,6,12-Graphyne through engineered B-N doping: DFT and Reactive MD simulations
summary: Graphynes offer a chemically heterogeneous $sp/sp^{2}$ carbon framework with distinct electronic regimes and site-selective reactivity. Here, Density Functional Theory and Reactive Molecular Dynamics Simulations are combined to evaluate pristine, B-doped, N-doped, and B-N co-doped $γ$-graphyne and 6,6,12-graphyne (meta/ortho/para). $γ$-graphyne is a semiconductor, while 6,6,12-graphyne exhibits an anisotropic Dirac-like semi-metallic dispersion. B/N substitution reconstructs near-$E_F$ states via dopant $π$ hybridization, and B-N pairing stabilizes defects through donor-acceptor compensation, with the ortho substitutions being the most favorable. Hydrogen adsorption remains weak on pristine lattices but becomes locally optimized upon doping, with near thermo-neutral $ΔG_{\mathrm{ads}}$ 'hot spots' predominantly on $sp$-proximate carbon sites adjacent to the dopants. Reactive MD at 300 K further reveals an activity stability trade-off: B-N ortho in $γ$-graphyne sustains controlled hydrogen uptake without catastrophic bond scission, whereas B-N meta/para degrade, and 6,6,12-graphyne is generally more susceptible to over-hydrogenation. These results identify the B-N geometry as a key design variable for graphyne-based HER catalysts, which require both a favorable $ΔG_{\mathrm{ads}}$ and finite-temperature hydrogenation stability.

AI.tldr: Graphyne materials with B-N co-doping show promise for hydrogen evolution reaction catalysts, with ortho geometry providing optimal balance between hydrogen adsorption strength and structural stability.
AI.motivation: To understand how boron-nitrogen co-doping affects graphyne materials for hydrogen evolution catalysis, specifically examining how dopant geometry influences hydrogen adsorption thermodynamics and structural stability.
AI.method: Combined Density Functional Theory and Reactive Molecular Dynamics simulations to evaluate pristine, B-doped, N-doped, and B-N co-doped γ-graphyne and 6,6,12-graphyne (meta/ortho/para configurations).
AI.result: γ-graphyne is semiconductor, 6,6,12-graphyne shows anisotropic Dirac-like semi-metallic dispersion. B-N pairing stabilizes defects through donor-acceptor compensation, with ortho substitutions most favorable. Hydrogen adsorption becomes optimized near dopants with near thermo-neutral ΔG_ads. B-N ortho in γ-graphyne sustains controlled hydrogen uptake without structural degradation.
AI.conclusion: B-N geometry is a key design variable for graphyne-based HER catalysts, requiring both favorable ΔG_ads and finite-temperature hydrogenation stability, with ortho configuration providing optimal performance.

title: Local smoothing estimates for bilinear Fourier integral operators
summary: We formulate a local smoothing conjecture for bilinear Fourier integral operators in every dimension $d \ge 2,$ derived from the celebrated linear case due to Sogge, which we refer to as the \emph{bilinear smoothing conjecture}. We show that the linear local smoothing conjecture implies this bilinear version. As a consequence of our approach and due to the recent progress on the subject, we establish local smoothing estimates for Fourier integral operators in dimension $d=2,$ that is, on $\mathbb{R}^2_x \times \mathbb{R}_t$. Also, a partial progress is presented for the high-dimensional case $d\geq 3.$ In particular, our method allows us to deduce that the bilinear local smoothing conjecture holds for all odd dimensions $d$.

AI.tldr: The paper formulates a bilinear local smoothing conjecture for Fourier integral operators, shows it follows from the linear case, and establishes results in 2D with partial progress in higher dimensions.
AI.motivation: To extend the celebrated linear local smoothing conjecture by Sogge to the bilinear setting, creating a unified framework for understanding smoothing properties of Fourier integral operators in both linear and bilinear contexts.
AI.method: Formulates a bilinear smoothing conjecture for Fourier integral operators, proves that the linear conjecture implies the bilinear version, and uses recent progress on linear smoothing to establish results in 2D and partial results in higher dimensions.
AI.result: Establishes local smoothing estimates for Fourier integral operators in dimension d=2, shows the bilinear conjecture holds for all odd dimensions d, and presents partial progress for d≥3.
AI.conclusion: The bilinear local smoothing conjecture is a natural extension of Sogge's linear theory, and the approach successfully connects linear and bilinear smoothing properties, yielding concrete results in low dimensions and odd dimensions.

title: Numba-Accelerated 2D Diffusion-Limited Aggregation: Implementation and Fractal Characterization
summary: We present dla-ideal-solver, a high-performance framework for simulating two-dimensional Diffusion-Limited Aggregation (DLA) using Numba-accelerated Python. By leveraging just-in-time (JIT) compilation, we achieve computational throughput comparable to legacy static implementations while retaining high-level flexibility. We investigate the Laplacian growth instability across varying injection geometries and walker concentrations. Our analysis confirms the robustness of the standard fractal dimension $D_f \approx 1.71$ for dilute regimes, consistent with the Witten-Sander universality class. However, we report a distinct crossover to Eden-like compact growth ($D_f \approx 1.87$) in high-density environments, attributed to the saturation of the screening length. Beyond standard mass-radius scaling, we employ generalized Rényi dimensions and lacunarity metrics to quantify the monofractal character and spatial heterogeneity of the aggregates. This work establishes a reproducible, open-source testbed for exploring phase transitions in non-equilibrium statistical mechanics.

AI.tldr: High-performance Python framework for 2D DLA simulation using Numba JIT compilation, revealing fractal dimension crossover from D_f≈1.71 (dilute) to D_f≈1.87 (high-density) and analyzing aggregate structure with advanced metrics.
AI.motivation: To create a high-performance, flexible framework for studying Diffusion-Limited Aggregation (DLA) that bridges computational efficiency with scientific reproducibility, enabling detailed investigation of non-equilibrium growth phenomena and phase transitions.
AI.method: Developed dla-ideal-solver using Numba-accelerated Python with just-in-time compilation for performance comparable to static implementations. Simulated DLA across varying injection geometries and walker concentrations, employing mass-radius scaling, generalized Rényi dimensions, and lacunarity metrics for structural analysis.
AI.result: Confirmed standard fractal dimension D_f≈1.71 in dilute regimes (Witten-Sander universality), but discovered crossover to Eden-like compact growth with D_f≈1.87 in high-density environments due to screening length saturation. Advanced metrics revealed monofractal character and quantified spatial heterogeneity of aggregates.
AI.conclusion: The framework successfully bridges performance and flexibility for DLA research, revealing density-dependent growth transitions and establishing an open-source testbed for exploring non-equilibrium statistical mechanics phenomena.

title: Global regularity for the Navier-Stokes equations with application to global solvability for the Euler equations
summary: We show that any Leray-Hopf weak solution to the $d$-dimensional Navier-Stokes equations $(d\geq 3)$ with initial values $u_0\in H^{s}(\mathbb R^d)$, $s\geq -1+\frac{d}{2}$, belongs to $L^\infty(0,\infty; H^{s}(\mathbb R^d))$ and thus it is globally regular. For the proof, first, we construct a supercritical space which has very sparse inverse logarithmic weight in the frequency domain, compared to the critical homogeneous Sobolev $\dot{H}^{-1+d/2}$-norm. Then we obtain the energy estimates of high frequency parts of the solution which involve the supercritical norm as a factor of the upper bounds. Finally, we superpose the energy norm of high frequency parts of the solution to get estimates of the critical and subcritical norms independent of the viscosity coefficient for the weak solution via the re-scaling argument.

AI.tldr: The paper proves global regularity for Leray-Hopf weak solutions to d-dimensional Navier-Stokes equations (d≥3) with initial data in H^s for s ≥ -1 + d/2.
AI.motivation: To establish global regularity for Navier-Stokes equations with initial data in Sobolev spaces below the critical scaling, addressing a long-standing open problem in fluid dynamics.
AI.method: 1. Construct a supercritical space with sparse inverse logarithmic weight in frequency domain. 2. Obtain energy estimates for high frequency parts involving supercritical norm. 3. Superpose energy norms to get viscosity-independent estimates via re-scaling argument.
AI.result: Any Leray-Hopf weak solution with initial data u₀ ∈ H^s(ℝ^d), s ≥ -1 + d/2, belongs to L^∞(0,∞; H^s(ℝ^d)) and is globally regular.
AI.conclusion: The paper establishes global regularity for Navier-Stokes equations with initial data in a wider range of Sobolev spaces than previously known, using novel supercritical space construction and energy estimates.

title: Study of the Effects of Artificial Dissipation and Other Numerical Parameters on Shock Wave Resolution
summary: The effects induced by numerical schemes and mesh geometry on the solution of two-dimensional supersonic inviscid flows are investigated in the context of the compressible Euler equations. Five different finite-difference schemes are considered: the Beam and Warming implicit approximate factorization algorithm, the original Steger and Warming flux vector splitting algorithm, the van Leer approach on performing the flux vector splitting and two different novel finite-difference interpretations of the Liou AUSM+ scheme. Special focus is given to the shock wave resolution capabilities of each scheme for the solution of an external supersonic inviscid flows around a blunt body. Significant changes in the shock structure are observed, mainly due to special properties of the scheme in use and the influence of the domain transformation procedure. Perturbations in the supersonic flow upstream of the shock are also seen in the solution, which is a non-physical behavior. Freestream subtraction, flux limiting and the explicit addition of artificial dissipation are employed in order to circumvent these problems. One of the AUSM+ formulations presented here is seen to be particularly more robust in avoiding the appearance of some of these numerically-induced disturbances and non-physical characteristics in the solution. Good agreement is achieved with both numerical and experimental results available in the literature.}

AI.tldr: Numerical investigation of five finite-difference schemes for 2D supersonic inviscid flows around blunt bodies, focusing on shock wave resolution and non-physical disturbances induced by numerical schemes and mesh geometry.
AI.motivation: To investigate how numerical schemes and mesh geometry affect solutions of 2D supersonic inviscid flows, particularly focusing on shock wave resolution capabilities and identifying non-physical behaviors in computational fluid dynamics simulations.
AI.method: Five finite-difference schemes are compared: Beam and Warming implicit approximate factorization, original Steger and Warming flux vector splitting, van Leer flux vector splitting, and two novel finite-difference interpretations of Liou AUSM+ scheme. Solutions are analyzed for external supersonic inviscid flows around a blunt body using techniques like freestream subtraction, flux limiting, and artificial dissipation.
AI.result: Significant changes in shock structure observed depending on scheme properties and domain transformation. Non-physical perturbations in supersonic flow upstream of shock were identified. One AUSM+ formulation proved particularly robust in avoiding numerically-induced disturbances. Good agreement achieved with existing numerical and experimental results.
AI.conclusion: Numerical schemes and mesh geometry significantly impact shock resolution in supersonic flow simulations. The choice of scheme affects both physical accuracy and appearance of non-physical disturbances, with one AUSM+ formulation showing superior robustness. Mitigation techniques like artificial dissipation are necessary for accurate simulations.

title: Riemann-Hilbert approach for the nonlocal modified Korteweg-de Vries equation with a step-like oscillating background
summary: This work focuses on the Cauchy problem for the nonlocal modified Korteweg-de Vries equation $$ u_t(x,t)+6u(x,t)u(-x,-t)u_x(x,t)+u_{xxx}(x,t)=0, $$ with the oscillating step-like boundary conditions: $u(x,t)\to 0$ as $x\to-\infty$ and $u(x,t)\backsimeq A\cos(2Bx+8B^3t)$ as $x\to\infty$, where $A,B>0$ are arbitrary constants. The main goal is to develop the Riemann-Hilbert formalism for this problem, paying a particular attention to the case of the ``pure oscillating step'' initial data, that is $u(x,0)=0$ for $x<0$ and $u(x,0)=A\cos(2Bx)$ for $x\geq0$. Also, we derive three new families of two-soliton solutions, which correspond to the values of $A$ and $B$ satisfying $B<\frac{A}{4}$, $B>\frac{A}{4}$, and $B=\frac{A}{4}$.

AI.tldr: The paper develops Riemann-Hilbert formalism for the nonlocal modified KdV equation with oscillating step-like boundary conditions, focusing on pure oscillating step initial data, and derives three families of two-soliton solutions based on parameter relationships.
AI.motivation: To solve the Cauchy problem for the nonlocal modified KdV equation with oscillating step-like boundary conditions, which has applications in nonlinear wave phenomena and requires specialized mathematical techniques due to its nonlocal nature and oscillatory boundary behavior.
AI.method: Develops Riemann-Hilbert formalism for the problem, with particular attention to pure oscillating step initial data (zero for x<0 and A·cos(2Bx) for x≥0). Uses inverse scattering transform techniques adapted to handle the nonlocal term u(x,t)u(-x,-t)u_x(x,t).
AI.result: Successfully develops the Riemann-Hilbert formalism for the Cauchy problem and derives three new families of two-soliton solutions corresponding to different parameter regimes: B < A/4, B > A/4, and B = A/4.
AI.conclusion: The Riemann-Hilbert approach provides an effective framework for analyzing the nonlocal modified KdV equation with oscillating step-like boundary conditions, and the derived two-soliton solutions reveal different dynamical behaviors depending on the relationship between amplitude parameter A and frequency parameter B.

title: Numerical Aspects of Gradient Reconstruction Schemes Applied to Complex Geometries
summary: This work primarily focuses on the study of three gradient reconstruction techniques applied to the calculation of viscous terms in a cell-centered, finite volume formulation for general unstructured grids. The work also addresses different ways of formulating the limiter functions necessary to maintain stability in the presence of flow discontinuities. The flows of interest are simulated using the compressible Reynolds-averaged Navier-Stokes equations, and the negative Spalart-Allmaras model is used for turbulence closure. Definition of interface inviscid terms uses the Roe approximate Riemann solver, whereas the interface viscous terms are calculated with a standard centered scheme together with appropriate definitions of the interface gradients. Steady state solutions are obtained using an implicit time-integration method, together with a novel convergence acceleration technique. This new approach defines a set of three simple rules for controlling the global CFL number based on the residue evolution. The work considers three test cases, namely, the subsonic bump-in-channel flow, the subsonic NASA high-lift Common Research Model multielement airfoil and the transonic ONERA M6 wing. Present results are compared to experimental and numerical data available in the literature. Severe numerical instabilities are observed when the simplest gradient reconstruction technique is used, while more sophisticated formulations are able to provide excellent agreement with the existing literature. Current results are demonstrated to be highly insensitive to modifications made to the numerical flux entropy fix terms. Integrated aerodynamic forces are shown to be mildly dependent on the limiter formulation used, even in the absence of shock waves. The proposed convergence acceleration procedure manages to quickly drive the residue terms to machine zero, provided no major instabilities are present.

AI.tldr: Study compares three gradient reconstruction techniques for viscous terms in unstructured finite volume methods, examines limiter functions for stability, and proposes a novel CFL control method for convergence acceleration.
AI.motivation: To investigate and compare different gradient reconstruction techniques for calculating viscous terms in cell-centered finite volume methods on unstructured grids, and to develop effective limiter functions and convergence acceleration techniques for compressible flow simulations.
AI.method: Uses compressible RANS equations with Spalart-Allmaras turbulence model. Roe solver for inviscid terms, centered scheme for viscous terms with different gradient reconstruction techniques. Implicit time-integration with novel CFL control rules based on residue evolution. Tests on three cases: subsonic bump-in-channel, NASA CRM airfoil, and transonic ONERA M6 wing.
AI.result: Simplest gradient reconstruction caused severe instabilities; more sophisticated formulations provided excellent agreement with literature. Results insensitive to entropy fix modifications. Aerodynamic forces mildly dependent on limiter formulation even without shocks. Proposed convergence acceleration effectively drives residues to machine zero when no major instabilities exist.
AI.conclusion: Gradient reconstruction technique selection is critical for stability and accuracy in viscous flow simulations on unstructured grids. Sophisticated gradient methods outperform simple approaches. The novel CFL control strategy effectively accelerates convergence to steady state solutions.

title: Quantitative Borg-Levinson theorem for the magnetic Schödinger operator with unbounded electrical potential
summary: The first author established in [8] a quantitative Borg-Levinson theorem for the Schrödinger operator with unbounded potential. In the present work, we extend the results in [8] to the magnetic Schrödinger operator. We discuss both the isotropic and anisotropic cases. We establish Hölder stability inequalities of determining the electrical potential or magnetic field from the corresponding boundary spectral data.

AI.tldr: Extension of quantitative Borg-Levinson theorem from Schrödinger operator to magnetic Schrödinger operator, establishing Hölder stability for recovering potentials/fields from boundary spectral data.
AI.motivation: To extend previous quantitative Borg-Levinson theorem results from the Schrödinger operator with unbounded potential to the more general magnetic Schrödinger operator, covering both isotropic and anisotropic cases.
AI.method: Extends the approach from [8] to magnetic Schrödinger operators, analyzing both isotropic and anisotropic cases, establishing stability estimates for inverse problems.
AI.result: Establishes Hölder stability inequalities for determining either the electrical potential or magnetic field from boundary spectral data, providing quantitative reconstruction guarantees.
AI.conclusion: Successfully extends quantitative Borg-Levinson theorem to magnetic Schrödinger operators, providing stability results for recovering potentials and magnetic fields from spectral data.

title: Recovery of nonlinear material parameters in a quasilinear Lamé system
summary: We investigate the inverse problem of determining nonlinear elastic material parameters from boundary stress measurements corresponding to prescribed boundary displacements. The material law is described by a nonlinear, space-independent elastic tensor depending on both the displacement and the strain, and gives rise to a general class of quasilinear Lamé systems. We prove the unique and stable recovery of a wide class of space-independent nonlinear elastic tensors, including the identification of two nonlinear isotropic Lamé moduli as well as certain anisotropic tensors. The boundary measurements are assumed to be available at a finite number of boundary points and, in the isotropic case, at a single point. Moreover, the measurements are generated by boundary displacements belonging to an explicit class of affine functions. The analysis is based on structural properties of nonlinear Lamé systems, including asymptotic expansions of the boundary stress and tensorial calculus.

AI.tldr: Unique and stable recovery of nonlinear elastic material parameters from boundary stress measurements using prescribed boundary displacements, with measurements at finite boundary points (single point for isotropic case).
AI.motivation: To solve the inverse problem of determining nonlinear elastic material parameters from boundary measurements, which is important for material characterization and nondestructive testing in engineering applications.
AI.method: Uses structural properties of nonlinear Lamé systems, including asymptotic expansions of boundary stress and tensorial calculus. Measurements are taken at finite boundary points (single point for isotropic case) with boundary displacements from an explicit class of affine functions.
AI.result: Proves unique and stable recovery of a wide class of space-independent nonlinear elastic tensors, including identification of two nonlinear isotropic Lamé moduli and certain anisotropic tensors.
AI.conclusion: The inverse problem of determining nonlinear elastic parameters from boundary stress measurements is solvable with unique and stable recovery, even with measurements at finite boundary points and using simple affine displacement fields.

title: Convergence to shock profiles for Burgers equation with singular fast-diffusion and boundary effect
summary: In this paper, we study the asymptotic stability of viscous shock profile for the Burgers equation $u_t +f(u)_x = (\frac{u_{x}}{u^{1-m}})_x$ on the half-space $(0,+\infty)$, subject to the boundary conditions $u|_{x=0}=u_->0$ and $u|_{x=+\infty}=0$. Here, the parameter $\frac{1}{2}<m<1$ measures the strength of fast diffusion. A key challenge arises from the pronounced singularity in the diffusivity $\left(\frac{u_x}{u^{1-m}} \right)_x$ at $u=0$ and the boundary layer. We demonstrate that the long-time behavior of $u$ converges to a shifted shock profile $U(x-st-d(t))$, where $d(t)$ is governed by the boundary layer dynamics at $x=0$ and driven by the initial data $u(x,0)$. To overcome the singularity from fast diffusion compounded by the bad effect of boundary layer for wave stability, some new techniques for weighted energy estimates are introduced artfully.

AI.tldr: The paper proves asymptotic stability of viscous shock profiles for Burgers equation with fast diffusion on half-space, showing convergence to shifted shock profiles despite singularities at boundary and zero diffusion.
AI.motivation: The study addresses the challenge of analyzing viscous shock profiles for Burgers equation with fast diffusion on half-space, where singularities arise from both the diffusivity term (which becomes singular at u=0) and boundary layer effects at x=0.
AI.method: The authors develop new techniques for weighted energy estimates to overcome the combined difficulties of fast diffusion singularity and boundary layer effects. They analyze the long-time behavior showing convergence to shifted shock profiles U(x-st-d(t)), where d(t) is governed by boundary layer dynamics.
AI.result: The paper demonstrates that solutions converge to shifted shock profiles, with the shift d(t) determined by boundary layer dynamics at x=0 and driven by initial data. The analysis successfully handles the singularities from fast diffusion and boundary effects.
AI.conclusion: The asymptotic stability of viscous shock profiles for Burgers equation with fast diffusion on half-space is established through novel weighted energy estimate techniques that overcome the combined challenges of diffusion singularity and boundary layer effects.

title: A new proof of unboundedness of Riesz operator in $L^\infty$ and applications to mild ill-posedness in $W^{1,\infty}$ of the Euler type equations
summary: In this paper, we first present a new and simple proof of unboundedness of Riesz operator in $L^\infty$ and then establish the mild ill-posedness in $W^{1,\infty}$ of 3D rotating Euler equations and 2D Euler equations with partial damping. To the best of our knowledge, our work is the first one addressing the ill-posedness issue on the rotating Euler equations in $W^{1,\infty}$ without the vorticity formulation. As a further application, we prove the instability of perturbations for the 2D surface quasi-geostrophic equation and porous medium system in $W^{1,\infty}$.

AI.tldr: The paper provides a new proof of Riesz operator unboundedness in L∞ and establishes mild ill-posedness in W¹,∞ for 3D rotating Euler equations and 2D Euler equations with partial damping, plus instability results for 2D surface quasi-geostrophic equation and porous medium system.
AI.motivation: To address the ill-posedness issue for rotating Euler equations in W¹,∞ without using vorticity formulation, which hasn't been done before, and to provide applications to other fluid equations.
AI.method: First presents a new simple proof of Riesz operator unboundedness in L∞, then uses this to establish mild ill-posedness in W¹,∞ for the specified Euler equations, and extends the analysis to other fluid systems.
AI.result: Successfully proves: 1) new proof of Riesz operator unboundedness in L∞, 2) mild ill-posedness in W¹,∞ for 3D rotating Euler and 2D Euler with partial damping, 3) instability of perturbations for 2D surface quasi-geostrophic equation and porous medium system in W¹,∞.
AI.conclusion: The work provides novel ill-posedness results for important fluid equations in W¹,∞, with the rotating Euler equations analysis being particularly significant as the first such result without vorticity formulation, plus applications to other systems.

title: Real-Time Inviscid Fluid Dynamics and Aero-acoustics on a Sphere
comment: All source code is made publicly available via the GitHub repository https://github.com/jstr01/RealTime-CFD-Acoustics-Sphere
summary:
Real-time fluid and aeroacoustic simulation on complex surfaces can have interactive applications - from globe-based weather visualizations to immersive computer games with physically accurate wind and sound. However, conventional grid-based solvers struggle with numerical instability near surface singularities, and mesh-based approaches lack a straightforward path to solving partial differential equations (PDEs) with stable, high-order accuracy.
  Our model presents a unified framework for real-time inviscid fluid simulation and aeroacoustics on spherical surfaces with embedded obstacles, combining the Closest Point Method (CPM), projection-based Navier-Stokes solvers, and the Ffowcs Williams-Hawkings (FWH) analogy. CPM enables surface PDEs to be solved in a Cartesian embedding without parametrization by restricting computation to a narrow band around the sphere. Each band point is mapped to its nearest surface location, where band operators project results onto the local tangent space. Surface obstacles are modelled with signed distance functions (SDFs), enforcing no-slip velocity constraints and Bernoulli-based pressure adjustments for consistent real-world boundary interactions. Aeroacoustic sources are computed directly from surface pressure force derivatives and mapped to real-time audio via frequency and amplitude modulation with artifact-suppressing hysteresis smoothing.
  Our findings from this model simulate the behaviour of inviscid fluid on spherical surfaces while generating sound using the pressure of the fluid flowing on the surface. This approach gives results that offer stability, geometric consistency, and support applications in scientific visualization, virtual reality, and educational tools.

AI.tldr: A unified framework for real-time inviscid fluid simulation and aeroacoustics on spherical surfaces with obstacles, combining Closest Point Method, projection-based Navier-Stokes solvers, and Ffowcs Williams-Hawkings analogy.
AI.motivation: Real-time fluid and aeroacoustic simulation on complex surfaces has applications in weather visualizations, games, and VR, but conventional methods struggle with numerical instability near singularities and lack stable high-order accuracy.
AI.method: Combines Closest Point Method (CPM) for solving surface PDEs in Cartesian embedding without parametrization, projection-based Navier-Stokes solvers, and Ffowcs Williams-Hawkings analogy for aeroacoustics. Uses signed distance functions for obstacles with no-slip constraints and Bernoulli-based pressure adjustments.
AI.result: Simulates inviscid fluid behavior on spherical surfaces while generating sound from surface pressure, offering stability, geometric consistency, and supporting scientific visualization, VR, and educational applications.
AI.conclusion: The framework provides a stable, geometrically consistent approach for real-time fluid simulation and sound generation on complex spherical surfaces with obstacles, enabling practical applications in visualization and interactive systems.

title: A sharp criterion and complete classification of global-in-time solutions and finite time blow-up of solutions to a chemotaxis system in supercritical dimensions
summary: We consider the chemotaxis system with indirect signal production in the whole space, \begin{equation}\label{abst:p}\tag{$\star$} \begin{cases} u_t = Δu - \nabla \cdot (u\nabla v),\\ 0 = Δv + w,\\ w_t = Δw + u \end{cases} \end{equation} with emphasis on supercritical dimensions. In contrast to the classical parabolic-elliptic Keller--Segel system, where the analysis can be reduced to a single equation, the above system is essentially parabolic-parabolic and does not admit such a reduction. In this paper, we establish a sharp threshold phenomenon separating global-in-time existence from finite time blow-up in terms of scaling-critical Morrey norms of the initial data. In particular, we prove the existence of singular stationary solutions and show that their Morrey norm values serve as the critical thresholds determining the long-time behavior of solutions. Consequently, we identify new critical exponents at which the long-time behavior of solutions changes. This yields a complete classification of the long-time behavior of solutions, providing the first such results for the essentially parabolic-parabolic chemotaxis system \eqref{abst:p} in supercritical dimensions.

AI.tldr: Sharp threshold phenomenon for chemotaxis with indirect signal production in supercritical dimensions: global existence vs. finite-time blow-up determined by scaling-critical Morrey norms of initial data.
AI.motivation: The classical parabolic-elliptic Keller-Segel system allows reduction to a single equation, but the studied system with indirect signal production is essentially parabolic-parabolic and lacks such simplification. Understanding long-time behavior in supercritical dimensions for this more complex system is needed.
AI.method: Analysis of the chemotaxis system with indirect signal production using scaling-critical Morrey norms. Construction of singular stationary solutions and using their Morrey norm values as critical thresholds. Investigation of threshold phenomena separating global existence from finite-time blow-up.
AI.result: Established sharp threshold phenomenon: global-in-time existence vs. finite-time blow-up determined by scaling-critical Morrey norms of initial data. Identified singular stationary solutions whose Morrey norm values serve as critical thresholds. Discovered new critical exponents where long-time behavior changes.
AI.conclusion: Complete classification of long-time behavior for essentially parabolic-parabolic chemotaxis system in supercritical dimensions, providing first such results for this system type. Critical thresholds in Morrey norms determine solution fate.

title: The Recovery of Semilinear Potentials Satisfying Null Conditions From Scattering Data
summary:
We construct oscillatory solutions of fully semilinear wave equations in Minkowski space satisfying a null condition of the form $$\square u:=(-\partial_{x_0}^2 +\sum_{j=1}^n \partial_{x_j}^2 )u= q(x,u)((\partial_{x_0}u)^2-|\nabla_{x'}u|^2),$$ $$x=(x_0,x'), \;\ x'=(x_1,\ldots, x_n) \text{ and } x_0=t \text{ is the time variable,}$$ on an interval $x_0\in [-T,T]$, $T<\infty$ arbitrary, which consist of the superposition of a non-oscillatory background solution and a single phase train of highly oscillatory waves of wave length $h\ll1$ and amplitudes given by powers of $h$; the waves interact with the nonlinearity and we measure the response $u(x_0,x')|_{x_0=T'}$ at a fixed time $x_0=T'<T$.
  We show that the coefficient of amplitude $h$ of the oscillatory part of the nonlinear geometric optics expansion of the solution determines the light-ray transform of a vector field associated with $q(x,u)$, which determines $q(x,u)$ uniquely in the maximal region determined by the data. Our methods also work for systems of semilinear wave equations satisfying null conditions, but in this paper we focus on the scalar case.

AI.tldr: The paper constructs oscillatory solutions for semilinear wave equations with null conditions and shows that the amplitude coefficient in the geometric optics expansion determines the light-ray transform of a vector field, which uniquely identifies the nonlinearity coefficient q(x,u).
AI.motivation: To develop methods for determining nonlinear coefficients in wave equations from oscillatory solution data, particularly for inverse problems where the structure of the nonlinearity needs to be recovered from boundary measurements.
AI.method: Construct oscillatory solutions as superposition of non-oscillatory background and single-phase highly oscillatory waves (wavelength h≪1). Use nonlinear geometric optics expansion and analyze the amplitude coefficient to extract information about the light-ray transform of a vector field associated with q(x,u).
AI.result: The coefficient of amplitude h in the oscillatory part of the geometric optics expansion determines the light-ray transform of a vector field related to q(x,u), which uniquely determines q(x,u) in the maximal region accessible from the data.
AI.conclusion: The paper establishes a connection between oscillatory solution data and the nonlinear structure of wave equations, providing an inverse problem framework for recovering nonlinear coefficients from boundary measurements of oscillatory waves.

title: Fujita exponents on quantum Euclidean spaces
summary: We study the well-posedness of a non-linear heat equation with power nonlinearity with positive initial data on quantum Euclidean spaces. We prove a noncommutative analogue of the classical Fujita theorem by identifying the critical exponent separating finite-time blow-up from global existence for small initial data. Moreover, we establish a fundamental inequality in general semifinite von Neumann algebras that is of independent interest and plays a crucial role in the study of global existence and local well-posedness of solutions of nonlinear equations in noncommutative setting.

AI.tldr: Noncommutative Fujita theorem for heat equation with power nonlinearity on quantum Euclidean spaces, identifying critical exponent for blow-up vs global existence.
AI.motivation: Extend classical Fujita theorem (critical exponent for blow-up in nonlinear heat equations) to noncommutative setting on quantum Euclidean spaces, studying well-posedness with positive initial data.
AI.method: Prove noncommutative analogue of Fujita theorem by identifying critical exponent separating finite-time blow-up from global existence for small initial data; establish fundamental inequality in general semifinite von Neumann algebras crucial for nonlinear equations in noncommutative setting.
AI.result: Identified critical exponent for nonlinear heat equation on quantum Euclidean spaces; established fundamental inequality in semifinite von Neumann algebras that enables study of global existence and local well-posedness in noncommutative setting.
