title: Continuum limit of hypergraph $p$-Laplacian equations on point clouds
summary: This paper studies a class of $p$-Laplacian equations on point clouds that arise from hypergraph learning in a semi-supervised setting. Under the assumption that the point clouds consist of independent random samples drawn from a bounded domain $Ω\subset\mathbb{R}^d$, we investigate the asymptotic behavior of the solutions as the number of data points tends to infinity, with the number of labeled points remains fixed. We show, for any $p>d$ in the viscosity solution framework, that the continuum limit is a weighted $p$-Laplacian equation subject to mixed Dirichlet and Neumann boundary conditions. The result provides a new discretization of the $p$-Laplacian on point clouds.

AI.tldr: The paper studies p-Laplacian equations on point clouds from hypergraph learning, showing that as data points increase with fixed labeled points, the continuum limit is a weighted p-Laplacian equation with mixed boundary conditions for p>d.
AI.motivation: The motivation is to understand the asymptotic behavior of p-Laplacian equations on point clouds in hypergraph learning, particularly in semi-supervised settings where labeled data is limited but unlabeled data grows.
AI.method: The method involves analyzing p-Laplacian equations on point clouds consisting of independent random samples from a bounded domain. The analysis uses viscosity solution framework and investigates asymptotic behavior as number of data points tends to infinity with fixed labeled points.
AI.result: For any p>d, the continuum limit is shown to be a weighted p-Laplacian equation subject to mixed Dirichlet and Neumann boundary conditions, providing a new discretization of the p-Laplacian on point clouds.
AI.conclusion: The paper establishes rigorous continuum limits for p-Laplacian equations on point clouds in hypergraph learning, offering a novel discretization approach with theoretical guarantees for semi-supervised learning applications.

title: Stability and Decay for the 2D Anisotropic Navier-Stokes Equations with Fractional Horizontal Dissipation on $\mathbb{R}^2$
summary: The stability problem for the 2D Navier-Stokes equations with dissipation in only one direction on $\mathbb R^2$ is not fully understood. This dissipation is in the intermediate regime between the fully dissipative Navier-Stokes and the inviscid Euler. Navier-Stokes solutions in $\mathbb R^2$ decay algebraically in time while Euler solutions can grow rather rapidly in time. This paper solves the fundamental stability and large-time behavior problem on the anisotropic Navier-Stokes with fractional dissipation $Λ_1^{2s}$ for all $0\leq s<1$. The case $s=1$ corresponds to the standard one directional dissipation $\partial_1^2$. Different techniques are developed to treat different ranges of fractional exponents: $0\leq s\leq \frac34$, $\frac34<s<\frac{11}{12}$, and $\frac{11}{12} \leq s <1$. The final range is the most difficult case, for which we introduce the spatial polynomial $A_2$ weights and exploit the boundedness of Riesz transforms on weighted $L^2$-spaces.

AI.tldr: The paper solves the stability and large-time behavior problem for 2D anisotropic Navier-Stokes equations with fractional dissipation in one direction, covering all fractional exponents 0≤s<1 using different techniques for different ranges.
AI.motivation: The stability problem for 2D Navier-Stokes with dissipation in only one direction is not fully understood. This intermediate regime between fully dissipative Navier-Stokes (algebraic decay) and inviscid Euler (potential rapid growth) needs systematic analysis.
AI.method: Developed different techniques for different fractional exponent ranges: 0≤s≤3/4, 3/4<s<11/12, and 11/12≤s<1. For the most difficult case (11/12≤s<1), introduced spatial polynomial A₂ weights and exploited boundedness of Riesz transforms on weighted L²-spaces.
AI.result: Successfully solved the fundamental stability and large-time behavior problem for anisotropic Navier-Stokes with fractional dissipation Λ₁²ˢ for all 0≤s<1, covering the full range of fractional exponents.
AI.conclusion: The paper provides a complete solution to the stability problem for 2D anisotropic Navier-Stokes with one-directional fractional dissipation, bridging the gap between fully dissipative and inviscid regimes through sophisticated mathematical techniques.

title: On the Ginzburg-Landau approximation for quasilinear pattern forming reaction-diffusion-advection systems
summary: We prove that the Ginzburg-Landau equation correctly predicts the dynamics of quasilinear pattern-forming reaction-diffusion-advection systems, close to the first instability. We present a simple theorem which is easily applicable for such systems and relies on key maximal regularity results. The theorem is applied to the Gray-Scott-Klausmeier vegetation-water interaction model and its application to general reaction-diffusion-advection systems is discussed.

AI.tldr: The paper proves that the Ginzburg-Landau equation accurately predicts dynamics near first instability in quasilinear pattern-forming reaction-diffusion-advection systems, with a simple applicable theorem based on maximal regularity results.
AI.motivation: To establish rigorous mathematical justification for using the Ginzburg-Landau equation to describe pattern formation dynamics in complex reaction-diffusion-advection systems near their first instability threshold.
AI.method: Develops a simple theorem applicable to quasilinear pattern-forming systems, leveraging key maximal regularity results from functional analysis, and demonstrates its application to the Gray-Scott-Klausmeier vegetation-water interaction model.
AI.result: Successfully proves that the Ginzburg-Landau equation correctly predicts dynamics near first instability, with the theorem providing a practical tool for analyzing general reaction-diffusion-advection systems.
AI.conclusion: The Ginzburg-Landau equation serves as a valid approximation for pattern dynamics in complex systems near instability, with the developed theorem offering a straightforward application framework for various reaction-diffusion-advection models.

title: On the dimension drop for harmonic measure on uniformly non-flat Ahlfors-David regular boundaries
summary: We extend earlier results of Azzam on the dimension drop of the harmonic measure for a domain $Ω\subset \R^{n}$ with $n\geq 3$, with dimensional Ahlfors regular boundary $\partialΩ$ of dimension $s$ with $n-1-δ_0 \leq s\leq n-1$, that is uniformly non flat. Here $δ_0$ is a small positive constant dependent on the parameters of the problem. Our novel construction relies on elementary geometric and potential theoretic considerations. We avoid the use of Riesz transforms and compactness arguments, and also give quantitative bounds on the $δ_0$ parameter.

AI.tldr: Extension of Azzam's results on harmonic measure dimension drop for domains with Ahlfors regular boundaries, providing quantitative bounds on parameters and avoiding complex analysis tools.
AI.motivation: To extend earlier results by Azzam on the dimension drop phenomenon of harmonic measure for domains with Ahlfors regular boundaries, while providing quantitative bounds and using more elementary methods.
AI.method: Uses elementary geometric and potential theoretic considerations instead of Riesz transforms and compactness arguments. Focuses on domains with dimensional Ahlfors regular boundaries of dimension s where n-1-δ₀ ≤ s ≤ n-1.
AI.result: Successfully extends Azzam's results on harmonic measure dimension drop, provides quantitative bounds on the δ₀ parameter, and achieves this using more elementary methods than previous approaches.
AI.conclusion: The paper demonstrates that harmonic measure dimension drop results can be obtained with quantitative bounds using elementary geometric and potential theoretic methods, avoiding more complex analytical tools.

title: Metric-uniform spectral inequality for the Laplacian on manifolds with bounded sectional curvature
summary: Given a Riemannian manifold $M$ endowed with a smooth metric $g$ satisfying upper and lower sectional curvature bounds, we show an equivalence property between the $\mathrm{L}^2$ norm on $M$ and the $\mathrm{L}^2$ norm on subsets $ω$ satisfying a thickness condition, for functions in the range of a spectral projector. The thickness condition is known to be optimal in this setting. The constant appearing in the equivalence of norms property depends only on the dimension of the manifold, curvature bounds, and frequency threshold of the spectral cutoff, but, crucially, not on the injectivity radius.

AI.tldr: The paper establishes an equivalence between L² norms on a Riemannian manifold and on sufficiently thick subsets for spectrally localized functions, with constants independent of injectivity radius.
AI.motivation: To understand how L² norms of functions with spectral localization behave when restricted to subsets of Riemannian manifolds, particularly establishing equivalence properties that don't depend on injectivity radius - which is important for applications where injectivity radius might be small or zero.
AI.method: The authors work on Riemannian manifolds with bounded sectional curvature and consider functions in the range of spectral projectors. They prove equivalence between the full manifold's L² norm and the L² norm on subsets satisfying a thickness condition, using geometric analysis techniques that leverage the curvature bounds and spectral properties.
AI.result: They show an equivalence property between L² norms on the whole manifold and on thick subsets for spectrally localized functions. The constant depends only on dimension, curvature bounds, and frequency threshold, but crucially not on injectivity radius. The thickness condition is proven to be optimal.
AI.conclusion: This provides a robust norm equivalence for spectrally localized functions on Riemannian manifolds with curvature bounds, with constants independent of injectivity radius, which has important implications for analysis on manifolds with potentially small or vanishing injectivity radius.

title: The Pohozaev identity for the Spectral Fractional Laplacian
summary: In this paper, we prove a Pohozaev identity for the Spectral Fractional Laplacian (SFL). This identity allows us to establish non-existence results for the semilinear Dirichlet problem $(-Δ|_Ω)^su = f(u)$ in star-shaped domains. The first such identity for non-local operators was established by Ros-Oton and Serra in 2014 for the Restricted Fractional Laplacian (RFL). However, the SFL differs fundamentally from the RFL, and the integration by parts strategy of Ros-Oton and Serra cannot be applied. Instead, we develop a novel spectral approach that exploits the underlying quadratic structure. Our main result expresses the identity as a Schur product of the classical Pohozaev quadratic form and a transition matrix that depends on the eigenvalues of the Laplacian and the fractional exponent.

AI.tldr: Proves Pohozaev identity for Spectral Fractional Laplacian, enabling non-existence results for semilinear Dirichlet problems in star-shaped domains.
AI.motivation: The first Pohozaev identity for non-local operators was established in 2014 for Restricted Fractional Laplacian, but Spectral Fractional Laplacian differs fundamentally and requires new approach.
AI.method: Develops novel spectral approach exploiting underlying quadratic structure, expressing identity as Schur product of classical Pohozaev quadratic form and transition matrix dependent on Laplacian eigenvalues and fractional exponent.
AI.result: Successfully proves Pohozaev identity for Spectral Fractional Laplacian, enabling establishment of non-existence results for semilinear Dirichlet problems in star-shaped domains.
AI.conclusion: Provides new mathematical tool for analyzing Spectral Fractional Laplacian problems, overcoming limitations of previous Restricted Fractional Laplacian approaches through innovative spectral methodology.

title: Günter Hellwig (1926-2004) -- in memoriam
summary: Günter Hellwig was the author of influential textbooks on PDEs and differential operators of mathematical physics, an enthusiastic and inspiring teacher to generations of engineers, organiser of PDE conferences at Oberwolfach and a pioneer in index theory.

AI.tldr: Biographical overview of Günter Hellwig's contributions to PDEs, mathematical physics, teaching, and index theory.

AI.method: Biographical/documentary approach summarizing Hellwig's career achievements and impact through his publications, teaching, conference organization, and research contributions.

title: Stochastically forced compressible Navier-Stokes equations with slip boundary conditions of friction type
summary: We study a mathematical model of a compressible viscous fluid driven by stochastic forces under slip boundary conditions of friction type. We introduce a notion of a weak solution that is analytically and probabilistically consistent with this model. Our main result establishes the existence of such weak solutions under slip boundary conditions on bounded domains with $C^{2+ν}$-boundary ($ν>0$). The proof of this result combines an extended version of the four-layer approximation scheme on the torus by Breit/Feireisl/Hofmanová (2018) with the convex approximation method for absolute value functions studied by Nečasová/Ogorzaly/Scherz (2023).

AI.tldr: Existence of weak solutions for compressible viscous fluids with stochastic forcing under slip boundary conditions of friction type on bounded domains.
AI.motivation: To develop a mathematically rigorous framework for studying compressible viscous fluids driven by stochastic forces with physically relevant slip boundary conditions, which are important for modeling real-world fluid dynamics problems.
AI.method: Introduce a notion of weak solution consistent with the model, then prove existence using an extended version of the four-layer approximation scheme on the torus combined with convex approximation method for absolute value functions.
AI.result: Established existence of weak solutions under slip boundary conditions on bounded domains with C^{2+ν}-boundary (ν>0).
AI.conclusion: The paper successfully develops a mathematical framework and proves existence of weak solutions for compressible viscous fluids with stochastic forcing under slip boundary conditions, combining advanced approximation techniques.

title: A half-space Liouville theorem for anisotropic minimal graph with free boundary
summary: In this paper we prove the following Liouville-type theorem: any anisotropic minimal graph with free boundary in the half-space must be flat, provided that the graph function has at most one-sided linear growth. This extends the classical results of Bombieri-De Giorgi-Miranda and Simon to an appropriate free boundary setting.

AI.tldr: Anisotropic minimal graphs with free boundary in half-space must be flat if they have at most one-sided linear growth.
AI.motivation: Extend classical Liouville-type theorems (Bombieri-De Giorgi-Miranda, Simon) to free boundary settings for anisotropic minimal surfaces.
AI.method: Prove Liouville-type theorem using analytical techniques for anisotropic minimal graphs with free boundary conditions in half-space.
AI.result: Any anisotropic minimal graph with free boundary in half-space is flat when the graph function has at most one-sided linear growth.
AI.conclusion: Successfully extends classical minimal surface rigidity results to free boundary problems, establishing flatness under growth conditions.
